Senior-Junior Debate
Set For Next Thurs.
The first Senior-Junior debate
in five years will be held next
Thursday at 11.30 a.m. in room
111), Latrobe Hall. Philip Grossman and Stanley M. Finkel will
represent the seniors, with Merel
Harmel and Morris Zucker speaking for the juniors.
The lower class, according to
Earl Wassermann, coach of the
Debating Council, which is sponsoring the contest, will uphold the
affirmative side of the question:

Weather affects one's mind, says
Prof. William

University of Illinois. The number
of patients who enter Illinois hospitals for treatment of mental illnesses
rises to a peak in June, drops to a
low point in September, rises again
in October and declines in November.

It looks like action and apathy on our part. The
weather is warm; beau.iful spring surrounds us, the
newspaper chatter is dwindling into accounts of Mrs.
Sinupson's trousseau, Oriole defeats, and Kentucky
Derby tips. Of course Spain is still the proving ground
for the German and Italian military, and Bilbao is on
the verge of starvation. But, times are better, business
is booming, stimulated largely by foreign armament
orders, but, so what?
Hence, this new campus activity has yet to function.
Some remember the short history of the Permanent
Peace Council, which last year was voted into existence
by the student body. Will this project meet a similar
fate? Maybe it has already.

FRIDAY MAY 7, 1937

Theory And Practice
Last week we called 0. D. K.'s activities for the year
"unimpressive." Yesterday before a handful of students, 0. D. K. tapped its new members.
The lofty ideals, purposes, and qualifications for
0. D. K. were expressed. For the most part, we cannot
help but feel that 0. D. K. did not live up to the standards
It has set up.

Our Place On The Campus
We are frankly a little perplexed by the naive, contradictory, and superficial observations noted by one of
our fellow-students who wrote the letter criticizing our
taking a stand on the Student Council Presidential elections. Of course, we are forced to agree with some of
his remarks, which refute his own statements. Suffice
it to say that with the main lines of his arguments, we
are in total disagreement.
We are a firm advocate of free speech and free press,
not in their terms' abstract and empty meanings, but
In tangible situations. We reprint all signed letters,
no matter how much we disagree with their content.
We believe the NEWS-LETTER has the right and the
duty to take a stand on all student issues. We believe
in presenting facts in our news stories, but opinions in
our editorials.

F. Petersen of the

brought close to home.

C. and D. papers wrinkled noses
with the medium-strength odor of
rotten eggs---hydrogen sulphide.
But the seven of the E and F class
rocked stomachs with the staggering
smell of rancid butter-----butyric acid.
Goldfish especially yellow ones by
the name of Othello, can rarely be
found flashing around a clean glass
bowl on the desk of a college newspaper editor.
And Othello wouldn't have made
his temporary home there if his mistress hadn't abandoned him at the
office of the Rice Institute Thresher.
Hasty pencil-scrawls on a white
sheet of paper left under the bowl,
explained tearfully that a "poor
woman" could not afford to support
little yellow Othello any longer and
would the editor, "a kind man," take
care of the poor fish? The note was
signed, "Broken Hearted."

We certainly hope we influence student opinion, otherwise we should be an ineffective campus newspaper.
But we realize that we cannot do this unless we are
fair-minded with our fact-gathering, unless we are logical in our judgment, and unless we present opinions
which appeal to the intelligence of the students.
We thought, after careful consideration that one candidate stood out. We still think so; we now know that
the campus thinks likewise. But we stated nothing of
the incompetence of the others and naturally believe
they were well-fitted to run. We desired a fair election,
and we feel we got one.
We do nut represent the University's official opinion,
and nothing could be further from our public contentions or actual attitude.
It is our solemn obligation to present our beliefs in
our editorial columns. As we have stated when we
first took office:
". . . But on the editorial pages---our sanctum saneforum-- we will present opinions and conclusions from
'lively, eager, inquiring' minds, based on all the facts
and phases obtainable on the situation or problem. We
will not be dictated to or dominated by any small group
or individual interest; we will not be guided by any one
fraternity, activity, or organization. Our decisions will
be amed at intelligently and logically. When we take
a stand it shall be firm and determined; but we will not
fear to alter or modify our views of the discovery if
new facts or viewpoints forces such a change. . . ."
So it is with this instance; we remembered our place
on the campus.

To Bill Kempton whom the campus has honored with
its most important and responsible position we extend
our congratulations.
We are sincerely happy to see the obviously bestfitted student receive this honor. We hope he realizes
the scope of his duties and devotes his capabilities and
judgment to their fullness in his new office.
The NEWS-LETTER extends its whole-hearted cooperation to the new head. , We hope we may work harmoniously in putting into effect some much-needed campus
reforms. We shall not hesitate to suggest, criticize, or
commend the future actions of the Student Council.

A Full Clearing Needed
This evening the Hopkins Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa
will meet to decide an amendment to its constitution.
This change is designed to prevent the possibility of a
recurrence of the unfortunate situation which arose several weeks ago.
We certainly hope that this amendment is passed.
It will add much to the respect of the public attitude
towards elections to Phi Beta Kappa. It is a change
which will make election much more fair.
But the question of the "rejected" seventh-ranking
student as yet remains unadjusted. But something can
possibly be done at this meeting. We hope that the
members of the Hopkins Chapter are sufficiently proud
of its reputation and are sufficiently possessed of a
sense of justice to carefully examine every angle of the
problem for a solution.

Weather affects one's mind, says
Prof. William

University of Illinois. The number
of patients who enter Illinois hospitals for treatment of mental illnesses
rises to a peak in June, drops to a
low point in September, rises again
in October and declines in November.

It looks like action and apathy on our part. The
weather is warm; beau.iful spring surrounds us, the
newspaper chatter is dwindling into accounts of Mrs.
Sinupson's trousseau, Oriole defeats, and Kentucky
Derby tips. Of course Spain is still the proving ground
for the German and Italian military, and Bilbao is on
the verge of starvation. But, times are better, business
is booming, stimulated largely by foreign armament
orders, but, so what?
Hence, this new campus activity has yet to function.
Some remember the short history of the Permanent
Peace Council, which last year was voted into existence
by the student body. Will this project meet a similar
fate? Maybe it has already.

Theory And Practice
Last week we called 0. D. K.'s activities for the year
"unimpressive." Yesterday before a handful of students, 0. D. K. tapped its new members.
The lofty ideals, purposes, and qualifications for
0. D. K. were expressed. For the most part, we cannot
help but feel that 0. D. K. did not live up to the standards
It has set up.

Our Place On The Campus
We are frankly a little perplexed by the naive, contradictory, and superficial observations noted by one of
our fellow-students who wrote the letter criticizing our
taking a stand on the Student Council Presidential elections. Of course, we are forced to agree with some of
his remarks, which refute his own statements. Suffice
it to say that with the main lines of his arguments, we
are in total disagreement.
We are a firm advocate of free speech and free press,
not in their terms' abstract and empty meanings, but
In tangible situations. We reprint all signed letters,
no matter how much we disagree with their content.
We believe the NEWS-LETTER has the right and the
duty to take a stand on all student issues. We believe
in presenting facts in our news stories, but opinions in
our editorials.

We certainly hope we influence student opinion, otherwise we should be an ineffective campus newspaper.
But we realize that we cannot do this unless we are
fair-minded with our fact-gathering, unless we are logical in our judgment, and unless we present opinions
which appeal to the intelligence of the students.
We thought, after careful consideration that one candidate stood out. We still think so; we now know that
the campus thinks likewise. But we stated nothing of
the incompetence of the others and naturally believe
they were well-fitted to run. We desired a fair election,
and we feel we got one.
We do nut represent the University's official opinion,
and nothing could be further from our public contentions or actual attitude.
It is our solemn obligation to present our beliefs in
our editorial columns. As we have stated when we
first took office:
". . . But on the editorial pages---our sanctum saneforum-- we will present opinions and conclusions from
'lively, eager, inquiring' minds, based on all the facts
and phases obtainable on the situation or problem. We
will not be dictated to or dominated by any small group
or individual interest; we will not be guided by any one
fraternity, activity, or organization. Our decisions will
be amed at intelligently and logically. When we take
a stand it shall be firm and determined; but we will not
fear to alter or modify our views of the discovery if
new facts or viewpoints forces such a change. . . ."
So it is with this instance; we remembered our place
on the campus.

To Bill Kempton whom the campus has honored with
its most important and responsible position we extend
our congratulations.
We are sincerely happy to see the obviously bestfitted student receive this honor. We hope he realizes
the scope of his duties and devotes his capabilities and
judgment to their fullness in his new office.
The NEWS-LETTER extends its whole-hearted cooperation to the new head. , We hope we may work harmoniously in putting into effect some much-needed campus
reforms. We shall not hesitate to suggest, criticize, or
commend the future actions of the Student Council.

A Full Clearing Needed
This evening the Hopkins Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa
will meet to decide an amendment to its constitution.
This change is designed to prevent the possibility of a
recurrence of the unfortunate situation which arose several weeks ago.
We certainly hope that this amendment is passed.
It will add much to the respect of the public attitude
towards elections to Phi Beta Kappa. It is a change
which will make election much more fair.
But the question of the "rejected" seventh-ranking
student as yet remains unadjusted. But something can
possibly be done at this meeting. We hope that the
members of the Hopkins Chapter are sufficiently proud
of its reputation and are sufficiently possessed of a
sense of justice to carefully examine every angle of the
problem for a solution.

By LEONARD RUBINGER
One of Baltimore's annual track
highlights will be staged beneath the
Homewood floodlights when the
Mason-Dixon Conference holds its
meet at the Hopkins Athletic field
Saturday afternoon and evening. Of
the institutions participating in last
year's affair all but the University
of Baltimore are again represented.
Hopkins, Washington College, Catholic University, Delaware, Gallaudet,
University, RandolphAmerican
Macon, and Western Maryland all
have eyes out for both team and
individual honors.
Washington College, holder of the
Conference title, leads the field and
Is slightly favored to repeat last
year's triumph. But competition will
be plentiful, for Catholic U., Delaware, Randolph-Macon, and Hopkins are strongly fortified in many
events. Of these four stalwart challengers, the Blue Jay squad has
about the best chance of upsetting
